items.title: Trump claims to be setting up meeting between Zelenskyy and Putin after talks with European leaders end – live
items.standfirst: US president says he began arrangements for bilateral meeting after calling Vladimir Putin following talks with European leaders at White HouseTrump tells Zelenskyy ceasefire not needed for Russia-Ukraine peace dealSketch: All smoke and no fire as Zelenskky emerges unbruised after Trump meetA Russian drone attack on a five-storey apartment block in the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv early Monday killed five people and wounded more than a dozen others, Ukrainian authorities said.The attack, which took place just before dawn, reduced part of the building to rubble and sparked fires on at least three floors, the region’s governor Oleg Synegubov said on Telegram. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump tells Zelenskyy ceasefire not needed for Russia-Ukraine peace deal
items.standfirst: President reverses ceasefire position but says US will give Ukraine security help and expresses hope for trilateral talksDonald Trump has ruled out a ceasefire in Ukraine as Volodymyr Zelenskyy and his European allies visited the White House to push for US-backed security guarantees as part of any long-term peace deal.The US president, who only last week warned Russia of “very severe consequences” if Vladimir Putin failed to agree to a halt the fighting, made clear on Monday he had reversed his position. Continue reading...

items.title: Zelenskyy’s European ‘bodyguards’: which leaders joined Trump talks in Washington?
items.standfirst: Presidents, PMs and heads of Nato and European Commission accompany Ukraine’s leader at White HouseRussia-Ukraine war – latest news updatesEuropean leaders gathered in Washington on Monday for Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s meeting with Donald Trump in the Oval Office, in a show of support for the Ukrainian president. Their presence came amid expectations that Trump would try to bully Zelenskyy into accepting a pro-Russia “peace plan” that would include Kyiv handing territory to Moscow. The Europeans have been described as Zelenskyy’s “bodyguards”, with memories fresh of the mauling he received in February during his last Oval Office visit. So, who are they? Continue reading...
items.content: Presidents, PMs and heads of Nato and European Commission accompany Ukraine’s leader at White HouseRussia-Ukraine war – latest news updatesEuropean leaders gathered in Washington on Monday for Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s meeting with Donald Trump in the Oval Office, in a show of support for the Ukrainian president. Their presence came amid expectations that Trump would try to bully Zelenskyy into accepting a pro-Russia “peace plan” that would include Kyiv handing territory to Moscow. The Europeans have been described as Zelenskyy’s “bodyguards”, with memories fresh of the mauling he received in February during his last Oval Office visit. So, who are they? Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says lawyers are drafting executive order to end mail-in voting
items.standfirst: Announcement comes days after Putin allegedly told Trump US elections were rigged because of postal ballotsUS politics live – latest updatesDonald Trump on Monday announced that lawyers are drafting an executive order to eliminate mail-in voting, days after Vladimir Putin told him US elections were rigged because of postal ballots.In a White House meeting alongside Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy, Trump said: “We’re going to start with an executive order that’s being written right now by the best lawyers in the country to end mail in ballots because they’re corrupt.” Continue reading...
items.content: Announcement comes days after Putin allegedly told Trump US elections were rigged because of postal ballotsUS politics live – latest updatesDonald Trump on Monday announced that lawyers are drafting an executive order to eliminate mail-in voting, days after Vladimir Putin told him US elections were rigged because of postal ballots.In a White House meeting alongside Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy, Trump said: “We’re going to start with an executive order that’s being written right now by the best lawyers in the country to end mail in ballots because they’re corrupt.” Continue reading...

items.title: Trump's endorsement of Kremlin lies 'problematic', researcher says
items.standfirst: FRANCE 24's Mark Owen speaks to Jaroslava Barbieri, Research Fellow at the Ukraine Forum of Chatham House, about the latest meeting between US President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. She says that Trump's endorsement of 'lies that the Kremlin has been consistently pushing' is problematic and that the 'dimension of justice as a key component for a durable peace in Ukraine is completely absent' from the talks.
items.content: FRANCE 24's Mark Owen speaks to Jaroslava Barbieri, Research Fellow at the Ukraine Forum of Chatham House, about the latest meeting between US President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. She says that Trump's endorsement of 'lies that the Kremlin has been consistently pushing' is problematic and that the 'dimension of justice as a key component for a durable peace in Ukraine is completely absent' from the talks.

items.standfirst: Ukrainian president says latest strikes have killed at least 10 people and intended to ‘humiliate diplomatic efforts’Russia-Ukraine war – latest news updatesVolodymyr Zelenskyy has accused Russia of trying to humiliate Ukraine and Europe by “deliberately killing civilians” before talks with Donald Trump in the White House to be attended by Ukraine’s president and a group of European leaders.Zelenskyy described the latest strikes by Moscow on four Ukrainian cities as “demonstrative and cynical”. At least seven people were killed in a drone attack on Kharkiv, including a small girl, while three were killed in another bombing in Zaporizhzhia, he said. Continue reading...
items.content: Ukrainian president says latest strikes have killed at least 10 people and intended to ‘humiliate diplomatic efforts’Russia-Ukraine war – latest news updatesVolodymyr Zelenskyy has accused Russia of trying to humiliate Ukraine and Europe by “deliberately killing civilians” before talks with Donald Trump in the White House to be attended by Ukraine’s president and a group of European leaders.Zelenskyy described the latest strikes by Moscow on four Ukrainian cities as “demonstrative and cynical”. At least seven people were killed in a drone attack on Kharkiv, including a small girl, while three were killed in another bombing in Zaporizhzhia, he said. Continue reading...

items.title: Zelensky urges Trump to bring 'peace through strength' against Russia
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Monday urged Donald Trump to exert "peace through strength" against Russia, echoing the US leader's own language ahead of a high-stakes White House meeting. "Russia can only be forced into peace through strength, and President Trump has that strength. We have to do everything right to make peace happen," Zelensky wrote on X. Analysis by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Emmanuelle Chaze.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Monday urged Donald Trump to exert "peace through strength" against Russia, echoing the US leader's own language ahead of a high-stakes White House meeting. "Russia can only be forced into peace through strength, and President Trump has that strength. We have to do everything right to make peace happen," Zelensky wrote on X. Analysis by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Emmanuelle Chaze.

items.title: Zelensky in Washington to discuss acceptable terms for peace deal

Details by FRANCE 24 correspondents in Ukraine and Brussels, Emmanuelle Chaze and Dave Keating.

items.title: Who will be at Zelensky's side for decisive talks with Trump on Ukraine-Russia war?
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said it was up to Russia to end its invasion, ahead of high-stakes talks on Monday with US counterpart Donald Trump, who is pressuring Ukraine to give up Crimea and abandon its NATO ambitions. The comments came hours before Zelensky and European leaders were scheduled to meet Trump in Washington, a follow-up to a summit between Trump and Putin in Alaska on Friday that failed to produce a ceasefire. Story by Morgan Ayre and Charlotte Lam.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said it was up to Russia to end its invasion, ahead of high-stakes talks on Monday with US counterpart Donald Trump, who is pressuring Ukraine to give up Crimea and abandon its NATO ambitions. The comments came hours before Zelensky and European leaders were scheduled to meet Trump in Washington, a follow-up to a summit between Trump and Putin in Alaska on Friday that failed to produce a ceasefire. Story by Morgan Ayre and Charlotte Lam.

clusters.ai_summary:
• President Trump hosted Ukrainian President Zelenskyy and European leaders at the White House.
• Trump claimed he initiated a meeting between Zelenskyy and Putin after talks.
• A Russian drone attack in Kharkiv killed five people and injured over a dozen.
• Trump stated he plans to end mail-in ballots via executive order.
• Former National Security Advisor H.R. McMaster discussed the meeting on "The Takeout".

items.title: Newsmax to pay $67M to settle Dominion Voting Systems defamation case
items.standfirst: Newsmax will pay $67 million to settle a lawsuit accusing it of defaming the voting equipment company Dominion Voting Systems over its role in the 2020 election.
items.content: Newsmax will pay $67 million to settle a lawsuit accusing it of defaming the voting equipment company Dominion Voting Systems over its role in the 2020 election.

items.title: Right-wing US network Newsmax to pay $67m over false 2020 election claims
items.standfirst: Newsmax has paid $27m so far, and will pay $20m in 2026 and $20m in 2027 to technology firm Dominion Voting Systems.
items.content: Newsmax has paid $27m so far, and will pay $20m in 2026 and $20m in 2027 to technology firm Dominion Voting Systems.

items.title: Newsmax pays $67 million to settle defamation case linked to 2020 election coverage
items.standfirst: The right-wing news channel Newsmax has agreed to pay $67 million to Dominion Voting Systems over its coverage of the 2020 presidential election. A trial had been scheduled for October.
items.content: The right-wing news channel Newsmax has agreed to pay $67 million to Dominion Voting Systems over its coverage of the 2020 presidential election. A trial had been scheduled for October. (Image credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images)

clusters.ai_summary:
• Newsmax will pay $67 million to settle a defamation lawsuit with Dominion Voting Systems.
• The lawsuit accused Newsmax of spreading false claims about the 2020 election.
• Newsmax shares saw an increase in trading activity on Monday.
• TeraWulf shares also climbed due to expansion plans and financing initiatives.
• Newsmax will pay $27 million immediately, with the rest in 2026 and 2027.

clusters.title: Woman agrees to plead guilty to selling fatal dose of ketamine to Matthew Perry
clusters.neutral_headline: Woman Pleads Guilty in Matthew Perry Overdose Case
bullet_summary: Reported by Reuters Top News, CBS News, Guardian World and others

items.title: Woman agrees to plead guilty to selling fatal dose of ketamine to Matthew Perry
items.standfirst: Jasveen Sangha becomes the fifth and final defendant charged in the overdose death of the “Friends” star to strike a plea agreement with federal prosecutors, avoiding a trial that had been planned for September.
items.content: Jasveen Sangha becomes the fifth and final defendant charged in the overdose death of the “Friends” star to strike a plea agreement with federal prosecutors, avoiding a trial that had been planned for September.

items.title: Hollywood's "Ketamine Queen" agrees to plead guilty to federal drug charges linked to Matthew Perry's death
items.standfirst: Jasveen Sangha, 42, agreed to plead guilty to one count of maintaining a drug-involved premises, three counts of distribution of ketamine, and one count of distribution of ketamine resulting in death or serious bodily injury.
items.content: Jasveen Sangha, 42, agreed to plead guilty to one count of maintaining a drug-involved premises, three counts of distribution of ketamine, and one count of distribution of ketamine resulting in death or serious bodily injury.

items.title: 'Ketamine Queen' accused of selling fatal dose to Matthew Perry agrees to plead guilty
‘Ketamine queen’ accused of selling Matthew Perry fatal dose to plead guilty
items.standfirst: Jasveen Sangha, fifth and last defendant charged in Friends star’s overdose to strike plea agreement with prosecutorsA woman known as the “ketamine queen”, charged with selling Matthew Perry the drug that killed him, agreed to plead guilty on Monday.Jasveen Sangha becomes the fifth and final defendant charged in the overdose death of the Friends star to strike a plea agreement with federal prosecutors. Having initially pleaded not guilty, her change of plea means she’ll avoid a trial that had been planned for August. Continue reading...
items.content: Jasveen Sangha, fifth and last defendant charged in Friends star’s overdose to strike plea agreement with prosecutorsA woman known as the “ketamine queen”, charged with selling Matthew Perry the drug that killed him, agreed to plead guilty on Monday.Jasveen Sangha becomes the fifth and final defendant charged in the overdose death of the Friends star to strike a plea agreement with federal prosecutors. Having initially pleaded not guilty, her change of plea means she’ll avoid a trial that had been planned for August. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Arbitrator orders 10,000 striking staff back to work after government intervenes – unconstitutionally, union saysUnion leaders representing 10,000 striking flight attendants have said they would be willing to go to jail rather than comply with an order to return to work, as Canada’s federal government seeks to end a bitter contract dispute that has halted hundreds of summer flights and stranded travellers around the world.Speaking to reporters on Monday, the national president of the Canadian Union of Public Employees said members would remain on the picket lines as part of a work stoppage that has halted Air Canada’s national and international operations during its busiest season.
